comments.commentBody:
How in heavens name do you get the idea of the heart-protectiveness of not adding oil at all, from this article? It certainly outlines a case, based on analysis of the resurrected study, that it might be best to avoid polyunsaturated oils. But, it does not even address the issue of not consuming oils. You also say that the conclusion at the end of the article does not discuss whether or not to add oil to one's food. But, Dr.Calder, whose e-mail is summarized at the article's end, does say that the new analysis might lead some to recommend lowering the consumption of vegetable oils and substituting animal fats but that he was not ready to conclude that at this point.

Finally, one of the study groups actually continued their regular diet which consisted of about 15 percent saturated fat. Presumably this could have included saturated oils. And, it was this group that had the better health outcomes.

Unless I have badly misinterpreted your comment, it seems like you are looking at this through the lens of the no-oil diets of Campbell and Esselstyn and have concluded that their strictures are the way to go. Who knows? You might be right. But, I certainly don't think the data presented in the article get you there.
Alternate theory.  Genes trump diet.
I read it and am still confused.

Em, that is just one data point.  My neighbor years ago was Swiss.  Her whole family had really high cholesterol, and they all ate lots of cheese, cream, mascarpone, and so on.  And they all lived into their 90s, mobile and clearheaded.

One thing most doctors don't seem to know is that losing a lot of weight can make your cholesterol go up for awhile. People who have eating disorders get high cholesterol sometimes. When I lost 40 pounds (which I had gained over a few years), my cholesterol didn't budge---stayed high. But 6 months later, it was suddenly a lot lower.

Remember when doctors wanted us all to have a very low total cholesterol? Then they modified that and said we should have high HDL. Now they say the important thing is for your cholesterol to be sparse and flaky, not dense.

As for saturated fats, I am not surprised to hear about contradictions. Saturated fats from the old days included meat and milk from grassfed animals---hence full of omega 3s. Saturated fat from today is likely to be from factory farmed animals---NOT grassfed, hence deficient in omega 3s. TOTALLY different foods, not comparable.

About 10 years ago, I was listening to a radio show on NPR. It was a talk from a Dr. from Stanford, who had also received a PhD. in public health. He had recently returned from Tibet or Mongolia, where he found very little "modern medicine" but he also found extremely good health. His general opinion was that Western Medicine was a bit of a sham. Outside of child birth, infant care, and emergency/trauma situations, Western Medicine caused more problems then they helped.

In his talk, he said that when he was in medical school at Stanford in the 50's, one of his professors on the first day of class, pointed to a great tome of learning that was the textbook of his class. The professor, then stated matter-of-factly that 50% of the "truths" in that textbook would be wrong in 10 years. The only problem was that know one knew which 50% it would be.

For a pungent and erudite take on this (imagine Nate Silver turning his attention on medical science) , read "Lies, Damned Lies, and Medical Science" in The Atlantic about a popular Greek medical statistician. Brilliant. http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2010/11/lies-damned-lies-and...

For a funny take on this, read, David Sedaris's refreshing experience with the medical world in France published in the New Yorker. http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2012/04/02/120402fa_fact_sedaris

And if anyone can tell me who that guy was on NPR, I'll be very grateful. Thanks

This is an odd comment.  For the vast majority of human history (99 percent or more) no foods were "expensive" because money and capitalism did not exist.  People lived in small bands of hunter-gatherers and shared food communally.  Fatty foods (such as organ meat from animals) may have been scarce at times, but not all the time.

For most of human history, fats and oils were incredibly expensive and people didn't eat much of them.

For most of human history, people have spent a good part of every day in motion and getting plenty of exercise(aka work.).

it has become accepted wisdom? Does that explain the disastrous mess of North American nutrition outcome? Billions have been spent in the search for the cause, no answers. Would identifying obesity define the cause? Of course.
I condemned the pyramid guide for being responsible for devastating food folly in 1992, weight gain in full swing, still advancing.
My offer: Defeat Obesity. reverse it, prevent it. Keep people out of hospitals and drug stores, no guides and diets, real food.

I'm afraid you have that backwards! It's the medical care cost of the chronic diseases that are caused by poor diet that are bankrupting medicare, and this country too. Keeping people alive with these diseases is tremendously expensive. Healthy old people cost the system very little money in comparison.
"Eat butter, lard, sugar and flour in abundance." A public service announcement brought to you by the Office of the Budget for the Social Security Administration and Medicare.

@adamas You are way off. You seriously need to read more. There is good information to support Cholesterol denialism as you call it. Cholesterol just doesn't work the way vegans and plant based followers want to believe.

http://eatingacademy.com/nutrition/the-straight-dope-on-cholesterol-part-i
http://eatingacademy.com/nutrition/how-did-we-come-to-believe-saturated-...

People have improving numbers on low carbohydrate high fat diets with plenty of oils. If it were bad for people this could not happen, but it does in many cases. Fat and oils are not the problem its the kinds and amounts of fats and oils in combination with other high sugar foods that cause the problem.

A well formulated Paleo type diet leads to great health with good cholesterols numbers. For many Paleo followers all the numbers are in good ranges. For some the LDL is a little high if you use the LDL is all that matters philosophy, but LDL isn't all that matters. Far more important is Triglycerides and HDL numbers and type of LDL.

Those with High HDL, low amounts of Type A LDL or small dense LDL, and low Triglycerides might have a decently high Total Cholesterol but are perfectly fine without heart disease.

@adamas

Animal fats may lead to inflammation which is one of the main causes of heart disease for those that get an ApoE gene test result of 3/4 or 4/4. Fish and seafood especially shellfish are great for these people though. Fish and seafood obviously have much different fat profiles than land animals.

http://www.askthelowcarbexperts.com/2013/01/35-dr-steven-gundry-high-fat...

Its a good idea to listen to the whole thing...but minute 29 has the part about the ApoE gene test. Most people are fine eating animal fats as long as they don't have a huge carbohydrate load that isn't used.

@adamas

http://jackkruse.com/brain-gut-6-epi-paleo-rx/

I forgot to post this diet which is very anti-inflammatory. If a test result shows bad numbers while eating animal fat it may be a good idea to get an ApoE gene type test to confirm. If you get a 3/4 or 4/4 it wouldn't be bad to avoid or eat animal fats besides fish and seafood sparingly.

@What me worry check out my reply to adamas a few comments up...assuming they approve it.

In case they don't.

Read the articles and watch the videos in the links.

http://www.jackkruse.com/brain-gut-6-epi-paleo-rx/

http://www.askthelowcarbexperts.com/2013/01/35-dr-steven-gundry-high-fat...

http://eatingacademy.com/nutrition/how-did-we-come-to-believe-saturated-...

http://eatingacademy.com/nutrition/the-straight-dope-on-cholesterol-part-i

That post is more detailed than this one.

For most people, a diet rich in grains (whole or otherwise) and starches will send your blood sugar and insulin sky-high, raise triglycerides, lower HDL, and flood the arteries with atherogenic small, dense LDL particles.

Saturated animal fats from well-raised, healthy animals (grass-fed beef or wild-caught salmon) are rich in vital nutrients, and fats from healthy, natural sources have never been shown to contribute to any health problems.
Great attitude, wonderful theories!
Become animal based and be healthy. Research of Weston Price.

Hah! I would suggest, speaking about confusing, that if you would like to be further informed, read Denise Minger at her rawfoodsSOS website on the true grit of the China Study. Or not - more lamb chops for me!
The Mediterranean diet uses a lot of olive oil!

This article is not worth the time to read it. Talk about confusing things.

People...there are tons of data out there to support a plant based diet for a long, active life. Fuhrman, Ornish, Esselstyn, McDougall, Campbell, etc. Oils are not that big a deal. Eliminate them and cook with water if necessary. All oils are fat, one way or another.

Articles like this bring to mind the necessity of more research needed for healthy eating plans. The Mediterranean diet has a great following with impressive results.
Our research funds need to answer some very basic questions now to reduce our Medical system costs that depends too much on Big Pharma, Big Hospitals, and Big Insurance.

I suggest anyone interested in their health watch the UTube video, "The Diet Wars" by Dr. McDougall, to bring clarity to the subject.
After all you've said, why not smoke?

A couple of quotes from my graduate school public health professors back in 1979. "just you wait. 20 years from now they are going to say that cholesterol is good for and sends the blood coursing through the veins."

Another said, "everything in moderation, including moderation."

Personally, I'm an omnivore. I don't eat processed foods and don't worry about animal fat. I don't over eat and drink plenty of red wine. I'm 61, and at a good weight and exercise at least 5 days a week. And I'm in quite good health. My mother lived to be 89. She had an egg every morning and a lamb chop every night, loved apple pie a la mode and See's candy. And oh yes, a baked potato swimming in butter.

We're all going to die some day of heart disease or cancer unless we get hit by a bus. Life is short, enjoy yourself. Just don't smoke.

Thank you for adding this information. Without it, the article is seriously compromised. I wish that the NY Times health authors would make more of an effort to include essential info like this in these reports.

The author should read this NY Times article from 2007 for an education on these issues:

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/07/magazine/what-if-it-s-all-been-a-big-f...

Are loopholes -- like the ones that give Big Oil many billions every year, and that let GE actually get paid money from the government rather than paying taxes, and that let Romney amass $100 million into his IRA by using offshore manoevers, and that let millionaires deduct the interest on their second million-dollar home on the lake -- are those "tax expenditures" or missed revenues?
Because if they are "tax expenditures" then closing them is consistent with the GOP position of cutting spending.
It seems like the GOP plays these games of semantics all the time to please their donors, rather than doing the right thing and doing what they say they will do.

Chris,
President Obama was my State Senator, he was my Senator in Washington and he lived in the neighbourhood. I know politics are different in the US but President Obama has always been far to my right politically. He would have been a centrist Progressive Conservative here in Canada before our conservative party was taken over by Republican wannabes.

Unemployment under 4% means more revenue for the government coffers which would translate into more spending. Neither side has any plan to get us out of debt. It's election year rhetoric that has spilled over into non-campaign years.

Agreed, and let the surplus accrued purchase our nation's foreign owned debt.

Increasing the eligibility age at a time when lifespan has increased only for the wealthier Americans is absurd at best.

The Social Security program has the easiest fix of all that should not be unpalatable; just remove the cut-off for paying Social Security taxes.  Why is it even there?  There is no cut-off for income taxes or sales taxes.  If an individual is hitting the limit on Social Security tax in this economy, they have no complaints.

Pardon me if I'm wrong, but I think President Obama's plan to reduce Social Security's cost-of-living increases wouldn't apply to the 102-year-old lady, or even to 65-year-old me.

Like Ryan's plan to "voucherize" Medicare, Obama's plan to reduce the cost-of-living increases in Social Security would apply only to those who are now 55.

When they turn 65 or 66, they would THEN see fewer cost-of-living increases. .

Lee, I'm over the hill, but I care about my kids and grandkids, and young people overall. The programs that served my own grandparents so well, and my parents, can serve my children and grandchildren, too. But only if we continue to repel the designs of the greedy privateers and tax-haters to destroy them. We've succeeded now for 80 years; we can do it again, as often as it takes.

They want their wars, subsidies, junkets, tax cuts, "incentives", and the rest. They had better leave the rest of us something to show for lives of effort and labor, or there will be trouble not only for us, but for them--whether they believe it or not.

Pres. Obama should not put the "big three" on the negotiating table. The Dems were so proud to have invited that 102 year old lady to the State of the Union Address, yet the president who she waited for hours in line to vote for, is going to make her pay down the national debt,by reducing her Social Security? The president and the Democratic Party should be ashamed of themselves. We already know the GOP has no shame, but the Democratic Party is the poor and middle-class' last defense against the tyranny of the Republican party.

No one really cares about the national deficit except the Republican Party. The rest of us care about jobs and our own personal deficits. Blame the sequester on the beltway madness. The progressives in Washington are the only people who don't live in a bubble. There's a real world out there. People are struggling day by day to make ends meet.. Corporate profits are up and workers wages are stagnant. It would really be a kick in the pants if the president lets the GOP take an axe to entitlements.

It's funny how people who are so rich that they will never need the social safety nets ,feel they have the right to deprive others, of what constitutes as a human right, not to be treated like an animal because you are poor, old or down on your luck.
